description: From Middle English drane, from Old English drān, from Proto-West Germanic *drānu, from Proto-Germanic *drēniz, *drēnuz, *drenô (“an insect, drone”), from Proto-Indo-European *dʰrēn- (“bee, drone, hornet”).
In sense “unmanned aircraft”, due to early military UAVs dumbly flying on preset paths. The verb sense derives from this sense.

entries.meaning: A male ant, bee or wasp, which does not work but can fertilize the queen.
examples: All with united force combine to drive / The lazy drones from the laborious hive.

entries.meaning: (now rare) Someone who does not work; a lazy person, an idler.
examples: he that gathereth not every day as much as I doe, the next day shall be set beyond the river, and be banished from the Fort as a drone, till he amend his conditions or starve.

entries.meaning: One who performs menial or tedious work.
(aviation) A remotely controlled aircraft, an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV).
examples: Several images of the compound were obtained via a drone overflight.
One team member launched a camera drone over the Third Pole.

entries.meaning: (Uganda) A Toyota HiAce or a similar van, especially one used by Ugandan state agents to kidnap opposition members.
(chiefly Internet slang) A person without the ability to think critically and independently, especially one who follows a group blindly; a non-player character.

verbs.description: drone (third-person singular simple present drones, present participle droning, simple past and past participle droned)

entries.meaning: (transitive, colloquial) To kill with a missile fired by unmanned aircraft.

description: From Middle English drounen (“to roar, bellow”), from Proto-West Germanic *drunnjan, from Proto-Germanic *drunjaną (“to drone, roar, make a sound”), from Proto-Indo-European *dʰer- (“to roar, hum, drone”).

Cognate with Scots drune (“to drone, moan, complain”), Dutch dreunen (“to drone, boom, thud”), Low German drönen (“to drone, buzz, hum”), German dröhnen (“to roar, boom, rumble”), Danish drøne (“to roar, boom, peel out”), Swedish dröna (“to low, bellow, roar”), Icelandic drynja (“to roar”).

examples: He chanted as he flew and the car responded with sonorous drone.

entries.meaning: (music) One of the fixed-pitch pipes on a bagpipe.
(music, uncountable) A genre of music that uses repeated lengthy droning sounds.
A humming or deep murmuring sound.
examples: The monotonous drone of the wheel.

verbs.description: drone (third-person singular simple present drones, present participle droning, simple past and past participle droned)

entries.meaning: To produce a low-pitched hum or buzz.
To speak in a monotone way.
